column1: ## noun : declension : paradigm / eg / subtype / irregular
## adj = a: declension (1, 2, 3, 1&2) : paradigm / eg / subtype / irregular

*Another set of n'l adjectives, similar to the above but differing in the adjectives for 1, 3, and 4, were the distributive n'ls: singulī, bīnī, ternī, quaternī, quīnī, sēnī, and so on. The meaning of these is 'one each', 'two each' (or 'in pairs') and so on.

*Adverbial numerals are (as the name states) indeclinable adverbs, but because all of the other numeral constructions are adjectives, they are listed here with them. Adverbial numerals give how many times a thing happened. semel 'once', bis 'twice', ter 'thrice, three times', quater 'four times', and so on.
*The suffix -iēns may also be spelled -iēs: quinquiēs, sexiēs, etc. E.g. equidem deciēs dīxī (Plautus) 'indeed I've said it ten times already'
*Proportional numerals are declinable adjectives. simplus 'simple', duplus 'twice as great', triplus 'thrice as great', quadruplus 'four times as great', and so on.

*These are often used as nouns: simplum 'the simple sum', duplum 'double the amount of money' and so on. E.g. duplam pecūniam in thēsaurōs repōnī (Livy) 'double the amount of money to be replaced in the treasuries'
*The n'l centum ('one hundred') is indeclinable, but all the other hundred n'ls are declinable (ducentī, trecentī, quadringentī, quīngentī, sescentī, septingentī, octingentī, nōngentī).
